answers.answer: Did your husband have an overnight home oximetry to get those night numbers on his O2 sats? You mentioned his breathing pauses - if he has sleep apnea, it can cause drops in O2sats at night. It also increases risk of cardiac issues, stroke, hypertension, & diabetes. Needing more sleep can be the body's effort to compensate for poor sleep. Some other symptoms of possible sleep apnea are nighttime urination, daytime sleepiness, weight gain (for some), impotence, short term memory loss, foggy thinking.A sleep study will determine if he has sleep apnea and how low his oxygen goes at night.

question: My husbands  O2 sats run around 90 at sleep and may go down in the 80's part of the time.  He has always run a slow heart rate (not uneven just slow) when he sleeps.  His daytime rate is not slow.  He is not nearly as active now as he has been in the past and feels tired a lot of the time even though he is sleeping more hours than he ever has.  He has always had trouble with not breathing for several seconds at a time in the night.  What do you think?
title: Low o2 sat related to bradycardia
